intro: Brassica oleracea var. taquetii, commonly known as the Abyssinian cabbage, is a rare and lesser-known variety of the cabbage family. It is native to Ethiopia and is characterized by its compact, head-like structure with tightly packed, pale green leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–50 centimeters and produces small, yellow flowers in the spring. Its botanical features include a thick, fibrous stem and a distinctive, slightly bitter flavor. This variety is of interest to botanists and horticulturists due to its unique morphology and potential for genetic research.
